headline.main: Romney Sees 'Political Consideration' in Chief Justice's Health Care Vote

docs.abstract: Mitt Romney, the Republican nominee, said reports that the justice had switched his vote suggested that the ruling was based on a "political consideration" rather than a legal judgment.
docs.snippet: Mitt Romney, the Republican nominee, said reports that the justice had switched his vote suggested that the ruling was based on a "political consideration" rather than a legal judgment.

docs.lead_paragraph: The very poor may end up ineligible for both Medicaid and for tax credits to buy private insurance because of a quirk created by the health care ruling.
docs.abstract: Editorial warns that substantial numbers of the very poor could be left without medical coverage in states that refuse to expand Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act; contends that it would be unfair for the poorest people to get no help while people with somewhat higher incomes get tax subsidies.
docs.snippet: The very poor may end up ineligible for both Medicaid and for tax credits to buy private insurance because of a quirk created by the health care ruling.

docs.lead_paragraph: Days after his spokesman said the requirement that people have insurance was not a tax, Mitt Romney said it was, aligning himself with the conservative voices in his party.

headline.seo: Romney, in Shift, Says Health Care Mandate Is a Tax
headline.main: Romney Now Says Health Mandate by Obama Is a Tax
headline.print_headline: Romney Now Says Health Mandate By Obama Is A Tax

docs.abstract: Presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney declares that Pres Obama's health care mandate is in fact a tax, shifting his campaign characterization of the law and aligning himself with the conservative voices in his party; remarks prompt renewed criticisms that he is willing to adjust his views for political expediency, coming two days after his spokesman said the requirement that people have insurance was not a tax.
docs.snippet: Days after his spokesman said the requirement that people have insurance was not a tax, Mitt Romney said it was, aligning himself with the conservative voices in his party.

docs.lead_paragraph: Thousands of Marshall Islanders have settled in northwestern Arkansas, where they find steady incomes but face health and cultural problems.

headline.seo: For Marshall Islanders, Hopes and Troubles in Arkansas
headline.main: For Pacific Islanders, Hopes and Troubles in Arkansas
headline.print_headline: For Pacific Islanders, Hopes and Troubles in Arkansas

docs.abstract: Thousands of Marshall Islanders have settled in northwestern Arkansas, seeking steady incomes while fleeing the disease and poverty that are rampant in their home country; Marshallese face strong cultural barriers to integration in the United States, and have had difficulty obtaining health care.
docs.snippet: Thousands of Marshall Islanders have settled in northwestern Arkansas, where they find steady incomes but face health and cultural problems.

headline.main: Romney, in Shift, Says Health Care Mandate Is a Tax

docs.abstract: Mitt Romney said the majority in the Supreme Court health care ruling was right to deem the individual mandate “a tax,” just days after an aide said he rejected that view.
docs.snippet: Mitt Romney said the majority in the Supreme Court health care ruling was right to deem the individual mandate “a tax,” just days after an aide said he rejected that view.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s decision on President Obama’s health care law has thrown a wrench into campaigns for control of the House and the Senate, Republican and Democratic leaders say.

headline.seo: Both Parties Wary of Overemphasizing Health Care Issue
headline.main: Wooing Swing Voters, Both Parties Wary of Overemphasizing Health Care
headline.print_headline: Wooing Swing Voters, Both Parties Wary of Overemphasizing Health Care

docs.abstract: Republican and Democratic leaders say the Supreme Court’s decision on the health care reform law has thrown a wrench into campaigns for control of the House and the Senate; they point out that overemphasizing the issue could turn off weary swing voters who, they fear, just want to put the issue aside.
docs.snippet: The Supreme Court’s decision on President Obama’s health care law has thrown a wrench into campaigns for control of the House and the Senate, Republican and Democratic leaders say.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mr. Griffith was a veteran of stage and screen when “The Andy Griffith Show” made its debut in 1960. He went on to delight a later generation as the lawyer on “Matlock.”

headline.main: Andy Griffith, TV’s Lawman and Moral Compass, Dies at 86
headline.print_headline: Andy Griffith, TV’s Lawman and Moral Compass, Dies at 86

docs.abstract: Andy Griffith, actor whose folksy Southern manner charmed audiences for more than 50 years on Broadway, in movies and especially on television, most notably as the sheriff on the Andy Griffith Show, dies at age 86.
docs.snippet: Mr. Griffith was a veteran of stage and screen when “The Andy Griffith Show” made its debut in 1960. He went on to delight a later generation as the lawyer on “Matlock.”

docs.lead_paragraph: A fresh wave of public opinion polls has been released in the last few days, measuring Americans' views of the Supreme Court and its decision to uphold most of the health care law. The surveys found Americans divided over the ruling, as they have been over the law since its enactment in 2010. The Pew Research Center found that 4 in 10 Americans approved of the Supreme Court's decision, and about the same number disapproved. Pew also found that despite the seeming great interest in the ruling on the health care law, nearly half of Americans were unaware the court had held up most of the provisions of the law. Three in 10 said they did not know how the court had ruled, while 15 percent said the court had rejected most of the law's provisions.

headline.main: Nation's Verdict: Americans Split on Health Ruling

docs.abstract: Caucus column; Pew Research Center finds 4 in 10 Americans approve of the Supreme Court's upholding of the health care law, and that about the same number disapprove. (M)
